docs.lead_paragraph: The following article is based on reporting by Anthony DePalma and Louise Saul and was written by Mr. DePalma. PHARMACISTS, legislators and drug manufacturers in New Jersey welcome newly proposed national standards for the packaging of overthe-counter drugs. They caution, however, that if the measures do not go far enough to protect consumers, stricter, statewide regulations - like those that have already been introduced in the Legislature and are in committee - might have to be enacted to supplement the Federal rules. Richard S. Schweiker, Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, last week formally approved uniform standards for nonprescription drug manufacturers to follow in providing tamperresistant packaging.

headline.main: STATE SET TO ACT ON OWN DRUG RULES

docs.snippet: The following article is based on reporting by Anthony DePalma and Louise Saul and was written by Mr. DePalma.   PHARMACISTS, legislators and drug manufacturers in New Jersey welcome newly proposed national standards for the packaging of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Tamper-resistant packaging will be required within 15 months on almost all nonprescription drugs on store shelves in the United States. Richard S. Schweiker, Secretary of Health and Human Services, approved the regulations today. They will be published in the Federal Register on Monday, and the first step will go into effect 90 days afterward. The regulation gives manufacturers great flexibility in designing protective barriers as well as labels that warn consumers not to buy products with damaged seals. The regulation includes a compliance timetable for different kinds of products.

headline.main: U.S. SETS UP RULES ON DRUG PACKAGES TO BAR TAMPERING
